nodes.bodyText: I installed windows 7 sdk based on instructions given from graalvm team info - but that was months ago;  has it changed ?

nodes.bodyText:
I think it depends if you used jdk8 or jdk11 based GraalVM/native-image.
windows 7 sdk fir jdk8 one, VS 2017 for jdk11
i used instructions from #7663

nodes.bodyText:
No the official message from the SubstrateVM team has not changed according to the github readme, but according to this thread it looks like the the Windows 7 sdk is only required for older versions of GraalVM and with Java 8.
It looks like if you want to run JDK 11 on a modern graal you'll need at least VS 2017:

The JDK 8 versions used Visual Studio 10. The Java team builds JDK 11 with Visual Studio 2017. There is a Windows implementation of GraalVM 19.3 that uses JDK 8. You can try this as a work-around until you get a newer VS version.

So I could update this here to link to VS 2017 and add instructions based on the JDK wanting to be used.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -47,6 +47,7 @@ sudo apt-get install build-essential libz-dev zlib1g-dev
 ----
 xcode-select --install
 ----
+* On Windows you'll need to install the https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/thank-you-downloading-visual-studio/?sku=BuildTools&rel=16[Visual Studio Build Tools]
 ====

nodes.bodyText:
@gsmet How would you like this worded?
* On Windows you will need to install the Visual Studio Build Tools:
** For JDK 8 based projects you need to install the https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=8442[Windows 7 SDK]
** For JDK 11 based projects you need to install the https://aka.ms/vs/15/release/vs_buildtools.exe[Visual Studio 2017 Build Tools]

JDK 8 is deprecated in master so no need to make things more awkward than necessary.

nodes.bodyText: a google search didn't reveal to me how to install graalvm with scoop - got a pointer ?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -75,6 +76,13 @@ On macOS, point the variable to the `Home` sub-directory:
 ----
 export GRAALVM_HOME=$HOME/Development/graalvm/Contents/Home/
 ----
++
+On Windows, you'll have to go through the Control Panel to set your environment variables.
++
+[TIP]
+====
+Installing via scoop will do this for you.

nodes.bodyText: Above I linked to the scoop bucket for Java. Once you install scoop, you'll have to enable the bucket scoop bucket add java and then install graal: scoop install graalvm. That installs the latest release (jdk 11), but theres also graalvm-nightly, graalvm8, graalvm8-nightly, graalvm11, and graalvm11-nightly.
nodes.diffHunk:

 ----

++
+[TIP]
+====
+Installing via scoop will do this for you.

nodes.bodyText: For VS 2017 the path is call "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\Community\VC\Auxiliary\Build\vcvars64.bat"
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -158,6 +166,20 @@ just pass -Dquarkus.package.type=native as a property on the command line, howev
 this allows native image tests to also be run.
 
 Create a native executable using: `./mvnw package -Pnative`.
+[[graal-and-windows]]
+[NOTE]
+.Issues with packaging on Windows
+====
+The Microsoft Native Tools for Visual Studio must first be initialized before packaging. You can do this by starting
+the `x64 Native Tools Command Prompt` that was installed with the Visual Studio Build Tools.
+
+Another solution is to write a script to do this for you:
+
+[source,shell]
+----
+cmd /c '"C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2019\BuildTools\VC\Auxiliary\Build\vcvars64.bat" && mvn package -Pnative'

nodes.bodyText:
@rsvoboda I updated this to cmd /c 'call "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\BuildTools\VC\Auxiliary\Build\vcvars64.bat" && mvn package -Pnative' as that's where the file lives when only installing the build tools.
C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017> gci -r | where name -eq 'vcvars64.bat'


    Directory: C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\BuildTools\VC\Auxiliary\Build

Mode                 LastWriteTime         Length Name
----                 -------------         ------ ----
-a---           3/18/2020  9:10 AM             39 vcvars64.bat
